description.text:
This air limiting cap was designed for competitive swimmers with Finis Snorkels that need to limit their air flow while swimming with a snorkel. Many swimmers tend to either buy a hard plastic snorkel cap or tape off the top of their snorkels to limit airflow.   
Best if printed in a flexible plastic (NinjaFlex!) and should fit most snorkels. If printed in PLA or ABS you may have to scale it slightly for a good fit.

For Printing I printed this upright. The top is at an angle and should print fine. Also I printed in on a Makerbot Replicator 2 in NinjaFlex with the following settings: Print Speed - 45mm/s
Temp - 230C
Perimeters - 3
Infill - 100% I will be uploading designs that fit better using PLA/ABS instead of NinjaFlex.
Housing to screw on a surface then clip in a circular smd led assembly.

The wire separators on my 1989 Toyota 4Runner (3VZE) were hopelessly broken and the only options I could find off the shelf didn't have the right mounting options to snap on to the timing cover like the stock ones.

Cover for the Rambo electrronics. New version 1.1 has hole for the z axis steppers, and fan holes moved more to center for better print. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/djQGewj9kEF

author: coreygeorge

title: Laser Cut MR16 LED Desk Lamp

description.text: This is a desk lamp I drew for laser cutting on my Trotec Speedy 100R. It features a swivel base, pivot arm with adjustable angle and fully tiltable lamp through 180 degrees and swivel through 360 degrees. All files were put together in Corel Draw X5

I wanted a decent desk lamp, didn't like what was commercially available so I drew this from scratch! there's room for Improvement but the nifty thing about it is it uses a standard MR16 12v 3 Watt LED bulb!................ available everywhere ( DO NOT USE HALOGEN as this will get too hot )
I think it's all pretty easy to figure out,Files are all CDR X5 files. Sheet size is 600mmx300mm to fit the Speedy 100R with black for Engraving, Red as a primary cutline and blue as a secondary cutline ( you'll have to change these colours to suit your laser cutter if it's not a Trotec machine ). one and a half sheets make up the 5mm parts ( base and arms ) and a half sheet for the 3mm parts ( lamp holder, pivots, switch plates and Ac socket cutouts ) The pdf is a datsheet for a commercially available 12v PSU adaptor I used ( I broke this out of it's casing, there's artwork in the 3mm sheet for a PCB holder, it fits in the base ) Some parts are doubled up for strength, specifically the base legs, The On-Off Switch Mount plates, the pivot parts and some of the lamp holder parts these are meant to be glued together for extra strength so watch for those! All holes are either 6mm or 4mm. I used cap screws with Nylon locknuts and flat washers for assembly.
I used a figure 8 AC PCB mount socket, 5mm for the outside then 3mm as a spacer and another 3mm cut to size for the rear dimensions............ the socket is fitted and all three pieces are glued together. The On-Off switch is recessed this is done using two pieces of 3mm perspex, the outer piece having a larger hole to accomodate the switch outer dimensions. Switch type is a standard press fit rocker switch.
Use any 3 and 5mm material you see fit, I used scraps of different colour perspex that I had lying around hence the Technicolor!!!
All I ask is if you build it post your own versions especially if you make some improvements
Oh by the way to hold the MR16 Lamp in place, you need to get one of those spring clips they use in the standard ceiling mount downlighter fittings that are commercially available. They usually sell replacements at most hardware stores
Enjoy!!!

title: GoPro Parrot Perch aka Articulated Arm

description.text:
This thing, once printed and assembled, becomes a GoPro articulated arm aka Parrot Perch clamped to an M8 threaded rod.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=491-wPty4Ck&feature=youtu.be

This thing consists of:

  • 3D Printed parts
    1.1 Adaptor x1
    1.2 Clamp x1
    1.3 Corners x2

  • Off-the-shelf hardware
    2.1 M5 Threaded Rod 250mm x1
    2.2 M4 x 16 Screw x1
    2.3 M4 Nut x1
    2.4 M4 Washer x1
    2.5 M5 Nut x 13
    2.6 M5 Washer x13

  • Tools
    3.1 Small Second Cut Metal File x1
    3.2 7mm Wrench x1
    3.3 8mm Wrench x2
    3.4 Screw Driver to match item 2.2 x1
    3.5 4mm Drill Bit x1
    3.6 5mm Drill Bit x1
    3.7 Chuck for items 3.4 and 3.5

  • Finishing
    4.1 Drill manually M4 hole located on wider edge of clamp.
    4.2 Drill manually M5 holes i.e. all remaining holes.
    4.3 Deburr all parts including gaps in Adaptor.
    4.4 Cut M5 threaded rod into:
    4.4.1 170mm length x1
    4.4.2 70mm length x1
    4.4.3 40mm length x1

  • Assembling
    5.1 Assemble as per illustration.
    5.2 Use original GoPro Adaptor screw to attach camera to printed adaptor.
    • Happy Making!

This is a tool for adjusting your cutters to the rotational axis of your lathe.  This will help to prevent breakage from facing with a tool set too high, or poor surface finish with the tool set too low, or too high.

The part is meant to be printed on it's back, with the bubble trough facing up. To complete the assembly you will need: One 608z skateboard bearing (readily available) One 5/16 steel shaft about 3 inches long. I cut two circlip grooves to hold the bearing in place, but two O-rings will work just fine, and will aid in dis-assembly and flat storage. One 9x40mm long spirit level. I just found these online, and they come in packs of 10:
http://www.banggood.com/10pcs-9x40mm-Cylindrical-Bubble-Spirit-Level-Set-For-Professional-Measuring-And-Normal-Use-p-979993.html One 10-32 x 1 inch socket cap screw with jam nut (a 10-32 cone point set screw works excellent as a precision alternative) The bearing should be a light press fit into the printed part, and the spirit level pops in by hand as well. The 10-32 threads I used a tap for, and a similar metric size should work just fine too. To tune it to your lathe, set the flat on the bottom of the tool on your lathe cross slide parallel to the chuck face. Turn your adjusting screw in until it just barely contacts the cross slide. LIGHTLY tighten the jam nut. You are ready to rock! If you are super picky, you can face the end of your screw before calibrating. IGES and STEP files are supplied for those who want to modify for a different Spirit level ETC.

comments.text: Yep, we used to teach tool centering without tooling. But students are often un focused and forgetful, and tooling is expensive. This tool has saved my shop hundreds of dollars in broken tooling, and takes away any excuses about not understanding the tool setup process. We aren't an apprenticeship program. We teach engineering students machining basics, so they don't design things in a vacuum. Maybe for a vacuum, but not in one

description.text: The rhombic triacontahedron is a polyhedron with 30 identical faces.  It can be a 30 sided dice, but by duplicating numbers on faces it can be used in place of dice with numbers of sides equal to any of the factors of 30. Versions representing dice with 5, 6, 10, and 30 sides are given.  Two "loaded" versions of the six sided dice are also given.  One has extra 3's; the other extra 4's.  They should show a 3 or 4, on average, once in 3 throws.  OpenSCAD code is included.
The dice were printed on a Replicator without support.  They work best if thrown on a hard surface and occasionally "quiver" before settling.

description.text: Frame for microquadcopter
Mount electronics on gear tray to allow freedom of battery placement

*UPDATE: Printed on 9/12 and it works! Took a little bit of cleaning up around the holes / caps, but everything fits. See updated pics Using some other designs I've seen, I designed my own formicarium. This one is smaller, measuring 130mm square, to better fit on my build plate. I've included a version with a lip at the top, which should accept a 125mm sq piece of glass. There are two large holes, which should accept 18mm test tubes One of them is inset quite a bit, so I plan on using that one for my water tube and leaving the tube embedded in the colony. The smaller hole is sized for the 7mm airline tubing I have on hand, to connect an outworld or another colony. I've also included plugs for the holes.
Just an 80mm fan plate for my rostock!  Figured I would share with anyone wanting to cool the bottom.  I noticed mine was getting real hot down there, with the power supply not breathing cool air.
I printed it at 20% infill at 200 microns.  Worked fine.  Pretty simple item so no need for quality-

author: 2xStudio

description.text: This is a versatile build-it-yourself dice tower that can be expanded and customized to as high as you can stack it. Once assembled, the middle sections can be twisted to change the path of the dice. Supports Settlers of Catan and standard D6 dice. Assembly demo of an older version with a hex-shaped tray: https://youtu.be/IiKTh4Hh0eY Dice demo: https://youtu.be/jdS_LXVL-bA If you print this, please kindly click "I Made One" and share pictures and videos! I love that stuff! Also, feel free to check out my other designs which are as diverse as they are many: http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs Oct 21st, 2015 update: Added the Spiral module... updated the Arch module and deleted the Banister module (dice always got stuck in that nook at the bottom!)... Enjoy! Oh, and "Happy Back To The Future Day!" Oct 30th, 2015 update: Replaced both Battlements and Spiral modules with improved versions. The Battlements modules now have 2mm walls and the Spiral module prints way easier (without taxing your poor printer with steep and thin angles like the previous design) Nov 14th, 2015 update: Added a round alternative to the Tray (featured in the new pink tower image above). Also, there's a larger version of the Modular Dice Tower here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1131768 January 25th, 2016 update: There's a nice V2 Base (it combines base and tray together into one piece) that I'm sure you'll like if you don't mind it being slightly less-modular: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1156522 February 2nd, 2016 update: Added the two Fig8 modules for a two piece base-tray combo. Essentially equivalent to the BaseV2 except it's now in made up of two parts instead of one. April 18th, 2016 update: Happy Tax Day!! To celibrate, I removed all the old-style tripod-shaped bases and hex-shaped trays, and V2 base (that's a 30% reduction of files!)... now, back to work, you!! :D

comments.text: At the interface of each modular part, a 45.2mm diameter edge circle slips into a 46mm diameter circle - which means you'd typically have about .4mm clearance gap all the way around if the pieces were printed with a 100% accurate printer (making them way too loose).  Most home printers fill this gap with about .3 to .4mm on both sides of freshly melted filament.  Given your feedback, your printer is closer to the .3mm resolution (maybe less?) so if you just get a crapier printer, then you'll be ok. :)

title: Gopro & Xiaomi Yi generic strap-on mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I didn't want to have a clumsy HD-camera mount on my Armattan Morphite 180 so I designed a generic mount that straps onto the same strap as the battery. Flight (and crash) testing has shown that the mounts works very well. If the crash is hard enough the mount and/or camera will just release from the straps. This mount should work very well for any multicopter with top mounted battery. An extra 10-15mm strap is used for the gopro/xiaomi camera. I have made the two variants in two angles, 10 and 25 degrees. Some velcro, neoprene or hot glue would work well to add friction and keep the Lxl-mount and battery in place. EDIT: I've added a longer L-mount which can be mounted under the battery for lower CoG. Shapeways S-mount (10 deg): https://www.shapeways.com/product/HLLJCQ84Z/
Shapeways S-mount (25 deg): https://www.shapeways.com/product/UFS7AWW6U/
Shapeways L-mount (10 deg): https://www.shapeways.com/product/KT8UJKZAX/
Shapeways L-mount (25 deg): https://www.shapeways.com/product/KYL5THVEL/
Shapeways XL-mount (10 deg): https://www.shapeways.com/product/DM3ULLMVW/
Shapeways XL-mount (25 deg): https://www.shapeways.com/product/XQGHCDW6R/ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LBB93OeYyBU

title: PCB mounting clips for 35mm DIN Rail

description.text:
This is a plastic clip used to mount PCBs with mounting holes to a 35mm DIN Rail. The photos and source files are designed to fit some bespoke boards, see the instructions below for information about altering them.  
All parts were printed on a Rev 4 Ultimaker in silver PLA using Cura 13.05.2 (beta) with the quickprint "Fast low quality print" setting.  
Update: 11-Jun-13 I've added another design, an endstop piece which is 5.5mm wide and makes use of an M3 bolt to clamp the piece to the DIN rail by closing the springy part. It could easily be added to the other pieces by merging some of the OpenSCAD code.

It's unlikely that these clips will suit your needs as they are but the OpenSCAD files are provided along with the DXF to allow easy editing. Alter the clip profile by editing the DXF using something like Inkscape and then recompile the scad file, the hole diameter and depth have been parameterised but you will need to alter the spacing by tweaking the translations.  
The holes are set to 2.9mm diameter which was sufficient for M3 bolts to create their own thread in and hold quite secure.

title: Dragon Climbing Tower - Beer Tap Handle

description.text:
This tap handle features a dragon perched on the side of a small tower, proudly displaying a shield (paint it with the name of your brew, or chalkboard/dry erase paint) and holding a mug in one of his claws.  
The full tap handle measures just short of 9" tall, 2" wide, and 2.5" deep.

I've included several versions of the tap handle to hopefully make things a bit easier to customize.
A few notes:
  • This uses brass thread fittings which can be purchased from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/E-Z-Threaded-Insert-Internal-Threads/dp/B0026GZU0Q/ref=pd_bia_nav_t_3?ie=UTF8&refRID=1N5V76Q1G5MT4JBV9DSY). If you'd like to model your own threading, I've included a hole-free version; I just felt this way is easier.
  • This was printed in ABS - I highly recommend taking some scrap ABS pieces (leftover supports, or from failed prints) and melting them in acetone in a sealed glass jar. This slurry makes an excellent glue/touch-up material after supports are removed.
  • I've included a few manual supports for the head and right arm, since meshmixer's support generator didn't handle that area well. There are also versions without any support, and one that is fully supported (ready to slice and print).
  • Top piece is 7.5" tall, which may not fit in everyone's build area without splitting the model.
    • Print the bottom piece (no supports needed), and attach the brass threaded insert - I used my ABS slurry to slightly melt the textured interior so the brass could screw in, and so that the plastic could conform around the threading when the acetone finished evaporating. Try to make sure it's going in straight as you screw it in. The top piece was a fairly difficult print; I had a number of print failures while iterating on the design, and it ended up being around a 9 hour job. After it finishes and supports are cut away, glue the top to the bottom piece with ABS slurry.

Small Pawn. First attempt.

Inspired by barrychuck's Tall TOM ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7063 ) and Zydac Cup Cake Extenders ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4716 ) I decided to raise the ceiling on my TOM by 50 mm. I sourced the longer screw stepper from Kysan directly ( http://store.kysanelectronics.com/servlet/-strse-69450/17HD011-dsh-200N/Detail ) and added a few micro servos to get the order up to USD 100 (minimum required there). Unfortunately the stepper was broken upon arrival (no measurable resistance between pin 3 and 6 as the 0.5 Ohm between 1 and 4). I have changed the longer leadscrew axle with the one in the TOM, so I could get this project finished and that is what you see in the pictures. I have contacted Kysan and hopefully will received a replacement or a refund. Update: Kysan has contacted me and informed that they are sending me another stepper with the 200 mm leadscrew and there is no need to send the broken one back - superb service and extremely fast response in less than 24 hours - they have a customer for life in me. LatestUpdate: Kysan shipped the new stepper by EMS so it took barely 4 days to be delivered from Beijing. Very impressive customer service! The 3/8" rod came from McMaster-Carr ( http://www.mcmaster.com/ ) part number 88915K213 ( 36" 3/8" Easy-to-Machine Stainless Steel (Type 303)). I cut the two new rods after I had raised the top to be absolute sure of the fit given the slight variations the extenders may produce. The extenders are designed to fit a TOM and its backside lack of space, therefore the difference between front and back. The back also have markings for self-tapping screws to hold the Z-end stop. Additional parts : You will also need 6 more M3 16mm screws and nuts from the original stach that came with the TOM, 2 countersunk M3 16mm ( for the back extenders connection to the back plate) and two self tapping screws to secure the Z endstop in its new place.

• Print 4 sides, 2 fronts and 2 backs - I printed all of them raftless with 2 extra shells for good measure.

  • Cut the supports that I designed to hold the pins out, so the pins can be inserted into the slots.

  • Remove the stepper and Z-rods holding the Z-stage and placing it on top of the BP.

  • Remove the Z-axis end stop - that will be installed in the back right extender later.

  • Remove the top plate and install the extenders (sides and front first, back last) - remember that the back ones have to be on the outside and install the Z endstop on the right back side before you install the extender in place - it is easier to do it that way.

  • Be careful with wires. You may need to increase the length of the wiring to the extruder and other things you have attached to the Z-stage (fans, lights, etc..).

  • Cut and install the new Z-rods (measure twice - cut once - place the long rod in its future position and mark it exactly).

  • Install the new stepper - you may need to change sides for the wire to reach the stepper board. There is no need to use the new brass nut that comes with the new stepper. It is identical to the one that comes with the TOM. Depending on how low your ABP is you may need to leave the cork out. In my case it was a question of 2 mm before I would need to drop the cork insulator.

  • Test the connections and the reach of the wires with the now 50mm longer Z-height - be sure you are not pulling wires out of their contacts. Adjust accordingly.

  • Rejoyce.

title: Laser Collimator for Telescope
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This 1.25" collimator is a tool to help align the primary and secondary mirrors in a Newtonian style telescope. The laser used is a pen style pointer. http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

Print without support.
Add 6 x M2.5 nuts and screws.
Insert a pen style laser pointer and centralise with the two sets of M2.5 alignment screws.
Insert collimator into telescope and adjust primary and secondary mirrors to get laser to bounceback to desired accuracy. Tip: Keep the laser on/off push button allways on with sticky tape. Loosen and tighten the rear battery screwable cover to switch laser on and off. You can attach to telescope with my "Self Centering Bush" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:91390 Crosshair grooves also printed for the addition of wire or thread. Since printing the prototype,I've modified the sight hole in the .stl to be a teardrop shape to aid printing without support. Here's a video showing how to use a commercial version:
http://youtu.be/N1asF3m2Mh0

comments.text: Where do you get your screws?
comments.author: ex-nerd

comments.text:
I'm in the UK, so i got mine from thesolutionshop.nl, as they were cheapest I could find over here. In the states https://www.chicagoscrews.com/ was the best priced I found I think (was going to get some sent to a friend until I found the dutch guys, they were either crazy expensive or cost a fortune to ship in the uk)
search for chicago screws, sex bolts or binding screws. you can get them on amazon.com, but I was after the ones with the hammertops which mean you end up with a plain dome on both sides.

title: BokitoKijker - Glasses for viewing gorillas and the like.

description.text:
This is a fun thing which I saw mentioned on a TV programme here in the UK called 'QI'. (Hosted by Stephen Fry). This was a repeat of an episode broadcast a few years ago which mentioned a rather alarming incident at the zoo in Rotterdam. You can use your favourite search engine to find precise details using terms such as 'Rotterdam zoo gorilla attack' but the story concerned a gorilla called Bokito who got rather fed up and annoyed at a lady who had been gazing at him for quite some time - perhaps trying to make a human-primate connection of some sort. The gorilla lept over the moat which was supposed to protect the public and attacked the unfortunate lady who survived but suffered multiple injuries.
It turned out that animals like gorillas don't like being stared at which led to an insurance company handing out the BokitoKijker - translates from Dutch as 'Bokito viewer' - as part of their advertising campaign to enable the wearer to look straight ahead but appear to be looking away to his/her left :-)
This thing is a 3D printed Bokito viewer, a little more hard wearing than the cardboard cut outs handed out in Rotterdam. I have used the arms and hinge design from leoedlin's Customizable Word Glasses to produce this thing as well as a printed copy of the 'averted eyes' graphic, currently downloadable free of charge from the dutch site shown in the instructions.

Print the PDF file of the Bokito viewer via this link: http://www.fbto.nl/fbto/assets/pdf/bokitokijker.pdf I used photo glossy paper - you will need something a little more substantial than normal copy paper.
Slice and print the GorillaGlassesComplete STL file. (I have included two other STLs - one with just the front part of the frame and second with the arms taken from leoedin's Customizable Word Glasses which is thing #58259).
Assemble the glasses by CAREFULLY inserting the arms into their respective hinges on the frame - watch out not to get the arms upside down! One handy dandy tip is to warm up the plastic forming the hinges on the frame before you try and push in the arms. This will soften the plastic enough to make the job a whole lot easier and once in place, you can gently push the hinge together.
Cut out the eyes from the PDF which you downloaded.
Now comes the tricky part - finding out where to punch small holes into the paper eyes so that you can see through them once fixed to the plastic frame. I found that the easiest way is to put the glasses on, look into a mirror and gauge whereabouts the centre of your eyes appear in the lens spaces - if you want to be super accurate you may need the help of someone else with a ruler.
Fix the cut out eyes onto the frame using adhesive. (I used CA - superglue - watch those fingers don't come into contact!),
Now push a pin or needle into the eye picture at the place previously measured.
Finally put them on and spook your nearest and dearest .... with the confidence that you can now observe gorillas at the zoo in the safest way possible.

comments.text: So now the guy on your left is going to hit you for staring...and you won't see it coming...

description.text: In honor of National Hispanic Heritage Month, I am promoting efforts to bring models that celebrate Hispanic and Latino culture and heritage to Thingiverse. What better way to start than a 3D model of the outline of Spain. Join the National Hispanic Heritage Month Group http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/hispanic-heritage Suggest models for the National Hispanic Heritage Month collection at http://www.thingiverse.com/DesignMakeTeach/collections/national-hispanic-heritage-month Blog post about this effort. http://designmaketeach.com/2015/09/10/brainstorm-hispanic-heritage-month-maker-challenge/ This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dpQSKbp0nau Created from svg file by ocal http://www.clker.com//clipart-2166.html
Extruded svg in TinkerCAD.

Bobu-san is the second son of Sanetomo Yamatoneko Amatsu Hitsugi, most respected, of the northern mountains in Japan. Bobu-san's grandfather was rumoured to have incredible strength. Bobu-san learned early on the arts of Jujutsu, Kenjutsu, and bamboo fish cooking. He is a fearsome warrior, and he can also shoot fireballs from his hands. Bobu-san is most welcome everywhere he goes, because of his great respect, and he travels widely (and stealthily). He is often seen laughing heartily with the villagers at local inns. And often not seen hiding skilfully in the forest. Bobu-San emerged triumphantly from a google warehouse model http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=9e18fae12cb773e85b68bbb17a3f1530&ct=mdsa from the lustrous JAOG, who lists 'Vulcanizing' as his occupation/hobby/corporation, and makes some truly kick ass anime models, which are tremendous cool. Intented to be a quick and clean netfabb.com job, Bobu-San is a fearsome warrior and battled us nigh in to the evenings in a week long hack-n-slash in Meshlab, Sketchup and Netfabb. Bobu-san does not waste time, he has been trimmed (mostly) of overhangs, and is designed to print well at 0% infill and a wall thickness of 1.5mm or so. The joints have just been poorly patched on, they are Ball and Socket with Hole by araspitfire Every vertex and edge in Bobu-san has been rotated unevenly, and sworn at creatively, via Sketchup. There are no guarantees in Bobu-sans world, oh no, the life of a lustrous ninja is so often fraught with nefarious affray. But we may all eat on hardy fish, and laugh loudly together beside the peaceful river in the end. Fade Out In Darkness: Bobu-san welcomes you, into the mystery, of Bobu-san. End scene

• 0% infill and a wall thickness of 1.5mm or so
  • bottom/top layer 0.6mm or so

title: Bullet Camera Suction Motorbike Helmet Mount

description.text: Chilli Technology HD Action Camera mount for motorbike helmet. Camera mount has a tilt action so can be adjusted to suit riding position. The 2 Printed parts sit on the Igus bearing to provide smooth operation. Instructions provide more details. Printed on Robox using Black as Night ABS sliced with Cura using supports Get your prints here: http://bit.do/3dprintz

Consists of Base & Cam Mount printed parts.
I used an Igus Bearing GFM-0507-05
http://www.igus.co.uk/iPro/iPro_02_0001_0000_GBen.htm?ArtNr=GFM-0507-07&c=GB&l=en
although I have attached the STL so you could print in a different material.
50mm Suction mounts were bought from ebay
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/291152160037?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&var=590323103650&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
Suction cups were mounted to the 1.5mm stainless plate by drilling a 9mm hole with a slot at either end and couple of M10 washers also cut open to retain the cups in place Assemble 2 x M4 screws into base part along with Igus Bearing.
Using M5 x 16 Countersink screw, secure into Cam Mount using M5 Nyloc Nut. It has to be a Nyloc nut to provide resistance for the "tilt" action and needs to be done up quite tight but should still swivel on the face of the Igus bearing. Camera is fitted using 2 x M3 x12ish screws and plain nuts. Stainless plate with suction cups is then attached to the mount using 2 x M4 x 8 button head screws. Attach to helmet.There should be enough play in the stainless sheet to bend to match the profile of other helmets. Enjoy!

title: Flush mount, clip on acrylic side panels to enclose Makerbot Replicator 2 style 3D printer

description.text: These are acrylic panels for the side openings on the Makerbot Replicator 2 style 3D printer and similar clones. The clips are made to be either Lasercut from acrylic or plywood, or 3D printed. The clips flush mount a 3mm acrylic (or poly-carbonate) panel to the 6mm thick PVC walls of the Replicator 2. The clips attach the panel securely, are easy to remove, mount flush, and don't require any additional hardware. Helps maintain the internal working temperature of the printer, keeps drafts and dust and pets out. These panels are part of a complete kit to enclose this style printer. Available at: http://drazzticaction.com/products-page-2/3dprinters/enclosure-for-makerbot-replicator-2-2x-3d-printers-and-similar-clones/

Its a Boo! from Super Mario.   
Solidworks files are located in the zip file. They are really messy because I modeled the whole Boo! as I went, then cut it up in solidworks. Anyway, they are there in case you would like to modify.

Print one of each file.
Insert pin into slot on the two body pieces to hold together.
Insert base into ghost. The teeth are a bit tricky. I was able to print them on a glass/hairspray bed without the need for any type of raft but that may be subjective. I used a small knife to clean out the first layer "smash" and then the holes are made to take a small piece of 1.75mm filament to hold the teeth to the mouth. just jam it in there. On the smaller two teeth the holes are shallow, I managed to get it to stay together glue-less but this will depend on calibration, first layer, size of filament pin, etc. Or you could try the whole ghost stl with support. I didn't try it. Printed fine in PLA, pretty much default settings, nothing crazy. I went slower for the teeth (60mm/s) 120mm/s of the body files, thanks to sailfish.
Modeled in Solidworks, good loft practice.

title: Retract calibration object - Single Width Seperated Walls

description.text: 3 walls that are  the minimum extrusion width on a raft. This is a very difficult object to print well that requires fine tuning many settings in both firmware and slicing.

Modify the thickness of the wall to be your nozzle width and it print it at a slow speed, around 35mm / sec. To make this print perfectly is difficult, but until you get this right, everything else will have problems.
You may need to modify :
E Jerk in Firmware.
Retract Acceleration in Firmware
Retract Distance in your slicing program.
Retract Speed in your slicing program.
Extra Length on restart after retraction.
Z Lift on retract (Hop)

When printing,

2) Print size of file for small toy-boxes and 1.5 or 2 x size for more useful boxes.
I will be adding more boxes, let me know if you are looking for a particular size.

title: Geeetech Prusa i3x extruder mount with fan and induction sensor

description.text:
An induction sensor and 30mm print fan mount based on 2d cad files received from Geeetech. Not pretty but pretty functional. USE THIS INSTEAD: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1109334 (Mine has an error.) Thanks to bkeevil for the fix. If you decide to use it, make sure to use all 4 mounting screws. I only used the bottom two and mine is sagging a bit, needs to tighten it every now and then Which is a bit annoying. How to add induction sensor and configure auto leveling:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Enable-Auto-Leveling-for-your-3D-Printer-Marlin-Fi/?ALLSTEPS I am using a previous version of this thing, because after I printed and installed it I realised the "air outlet tube" could be a bit lower, closer to the print bed. I fixed this and uploaded it but have not tested it. If you try it please let me how if it works. If you dont want to use a cooling fan have a look at this tiny induction sensor mount instead: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001361
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online if you want: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lQbdcAwuKNv I have since removed the induction sensor as its detection distance got shorter and shorter. Probably because it was a chinese ebay sensor i had connected through a voltage divider made from chinese ebay resistors... I like ebay but sometimes the crap I buy is crap :)

Print it, sand/file the "stickouts" that should fit into the x-carriage mounting plate if neccessary, drill holes for fan, install fan, install induction sensor, install print head, configure firmware, and enjoy.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Customized version of Pentomizer - Every known tessellating convex pentagon Customize your own, it's easy! This is a desk organizer based on one of five tessellating pentagons discovered in 1918 by mathematician Karl Reinhardt. The four compartments of the organizer each have the same irregular pentagon base, and the resulting four-pentagon pattern can be used to tile the plane. That means that if you print more than one of these desk organizers, that they will fit together! Read more about pentagons that tile the plane:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentagonal_tiling

author: blanius

description.text: Anti gravity turbo faerie.

Put an end to your filament end getting tangled up in the loose outer wraps of your spool.  Assemble this clip onto your brand new spool and leave it there until the spool is finished.  It rides along with the spool while you print, then tuck the free end of the filament into the retaining slot for storage.  Because filament always stays threaded through the gap, it never gets the chance to flop loose and get tangled up. It prints up fast, so print one for every spool!

Print one of each part with 0.2mm layer thickness and 0.4mm line width.  The two parts click or slide together and the width can be adjusted for your particular spool.  The default size works for most ~8" dia. spools, but you should be able to scale the X axis for larger diameter spools.  
Keep the filament fed through the slot at all times.  When you want to store the spool, just press the free end of the filament into the tapered slot on the side.  
This version is for 1.75mm dia. filament only.

Should be a good addition to a project I'm working on and will upload after I get the 1.75mm version and do more testing with the 3mm version. author: braveheart

title: Desk stand for Samsung Galaxy Note

description.text:
A desk stand for the Samsung Galaxy note wearing a hard protective case.  It is mainly intended to hold the device in landscape orientation at a shallow angle of 30 degrees which I find the best orientation both to glance at it as well as to write and sketch with the S-Pen.  
You may need to adjust the dimensions to fit your protective shell.  
It can however also be stood at a steeper angle of 60 degrees by simply tipping it backward as in the photo and even in portrait orientation by putting it on its side.  However in these orientation it does not sit on the rubber feet but still good enough to view - it just is more liable to slide around.

Print with raft and full support.   
On Skeinforge I used cross hatching for the support. I also set a very slow flow rate for the support to make the supports fragile and easy to remove.  
I also included a half cylinder support under the central cylinder. This is to prevent it from sagging as happened in my first print of this thing. It is quite easy to break off after printing.  
Clean out the interior of the feet properly from any remnants of support and stick 16mm felt or rubber non slip self adhesive feet.   
I included the .skp file. This should make it quite easy to adjust the dimensions to better fit you protective case, or even to fit the phone without the protective case.  
I guess it should also be quite easy to adapt it to other phones or even tablets if your printer is large enough.

comments.text: It is fine for charging when the stand is in either landscape (horizontal) position, as in the first, second, third and the fifth picture. However in the portrait (vertical - picture 4) direction it is not possible to charge because the USB port will be almost touching the table surface so there is no room for the charging cable to plug in.

A bi-directional, one-digit, base-10 mechanical counter. It is designed such that strings should be attached to the 'ratchet pulling arms' , and a rubber-band should connect both ratchet pulling arms to one another, looping around an m3 bolt protruding from the zero_detect_frame block.

Print out 1 copy of all of the pieces, and two copies of the ratchet_pulling_arms. 693 bearings are used in the string_pulley and in the zero_detect_arm. 623 bearings are used in the ratchet_gear and the front of the zero_detect_arm (the bearing that rolls along the counter wheel). A spring (or rubber band) should be stretched from the hook hanging down from the zero_detect_arm to the same screw the rubber band connecting the pulling arms is wrapped around. A 1/4" diameter spring, about .3" long is used to force the ratchet_detent_arm into place. Liberally apply M3 nuts and bolts to secure everything.   
You should be able to increment and decrement the counter by pulling on either one of the strings.

remixed_from.title: Halo 4 Needler prop weapon with .SLT files

title: Halo 4 Needler Prop Weapon, For small build platforms
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Check out Printing the Revolution's video detailing the build and finish of this design. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F0XdU6xF-8o Feeling generous and want to support my design work? Visit my Myminifactory page and leave a tip, It would be greatly appreciated.
https://www.myminifactory.com/users/EthanNewhouse I got a lot of requests to create a version for small build plates, so I hope this satisfies this need. If these parts do not fit your platform let me know in the comments and I will try to fix the problem. This model has no previsions for electronics. Happy Printing!

The printing specs I am using are as follows. .4mm nozzle, .3mm layer height, support everywhere @35 degrees, 5 perimeters, 5 bottom and top solid layers, 60mm/s support and infill speed, 40mm/s outside perimeter speed, raft at .2mm air gap.  
Each part is cut into segments that may be printed in the single color as it appears in game, purple, pink, grey, black.....  
Print one of everything except for as follows. Print 8 alignment pin 9.5x38, print 38 alignment pin 9.5x18, 14 Needler alignment pins, print 4 LED holder front tip, print 7 LED holder back, print 14 Needles.  
Please upload any makes. Happy printing!

title: Cleome/Cleophee Costume Jewelry from the anime Wakfu

description.text:
This is a set of earrings and hair bands that are worn by the character Cleome (Cleophee in the undubbed French version) from the anime, "Wakfu".  
Designed in OpenSCAD.

I printed from Cura 15.04 with the following parameters:
Layer height 0.2mm,
Shell thickness: .8mm
Fill Bottom/Top thickness: 0.8mm
Fill Density: 15% The larger hole in the hairband is intended to conceal an elastic hairband under the plastic one. The earrings has a 4mm gap. They were made to go on a set of costume elf ears, but I managed to squeeze one onto my earlobe without much pain. I comes off easier than it went on. ; j

description.text: Here's a body, neck and platform for a bobblehead based on 3d-decoratie's "man" model.  You can use it to make a bobblehead of just about anything.  It works great with 3d scans, game characters, scanned art,etc.  The pictured bobblehead is of myself :D!

This will need to be scaled down considerably.  Print with support.  Model actually came out surprisingly well at .2mm layer height.  Take a spring (a variety of sizes will work) and put it over the neck.  Apply a tiny amount of glue to the top and bottom of spring after putting on a head of your choosing.  Bobble away!

title: Super Mario Warp Tube Planter and Brick Tray

description.text:
This is a Super Mario Warp Tube planter and Brick Trays. I created two different trays: one with a base and one with an open hole that you can add your own tray.  
Designed in Sketchup.

I printed the tube upside down due to the large overhangs where the head and body meet.   
I also printed it without supports to not use so much filament. It still did a decent job at covering the base of the tube, though it's a bit messy.   
I did have some problems separating the raft from the top of the tube, but was able to sand that down for the most part.  
The bases took me several tries and the final one was close enough.

author: nelmasri

description.text:
A slide on cover for the iSmartAlarm remote tag - this prevents accidental presses of the over sensitive buttons, while still allowing access to the battery cover and allowing the user to see the LED.  
Thephotos of the white cover are from one of the first prototypes, the black one is the latest with the best fit and the LED hole.
Print this face down, with 1mm support for the back edges.  This is snug fit, so it won't fall off easily, but a little force slides it off easily.

remixed_from.title: Fatshark 600TVL pivot mount for RCExplorer V3 (Nose spacer)

description.text:
Design goals:
  • A FPV mount that allows the camera angle to be easily be adjusted
  • Ability to set back camera to avoid damage during crash
  • The camera needed to stay in position
  • The Fatshark 600TVL camera case is universal
  • An offset camera mount is provided to accommodate different ZMR quad configurations. Additional mounts can be made for different aircraft configurations.
    To meet the design goals vitamins (nuts and bolts) were used. Eating your vitamins gives you configuration and durability. :-)
    • Background:
    I found many inspiring Thingiverse camera mount ideas. Thank you for sharing. Some printed OK but many were unique to the author's printer. The prior art has inspired me to create a design that can be easily extended to other FPV aircraft. AutoCAD 123D source files included. Remix it.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Vitamins:
  • (2) - M2.5 x 10mm bolt
  • (2) - M2.5 x Nut
    • Infill : 80% minimum

This is a new & improved, 10-hook mechanical punch card reader. It uses a couple 1/4" diameter springs, 693-bearings, and thin brass rods, as well as tons of M3 nuts/bolts, but is otherwise entirely 3D-printed on my Thing-o-Matic. Turning the crank 'reads' the punch card (the direction does not matter), raising hooks where holes have been punched in the instruction cards.

The instructions are pretty much the same as here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33696, with a few modifications where parts changed. Assemble the main frame, and wait to add the hooks / needles until the end. The 'back needle holder' should be inserted with the 'slots' facing upward. To insert the hooks/needles:
  • Rotate the back needle holder backwards slightly
  • Insert a hook so that it is resting on the hook_pivot_support, with the 'hook' part pointing towards the card cylinder.
  • Place a 1/4" diameter spring on the back of the 'needle', and place the hook in the needle around the hook.
  • Bend the needle down slightly so that you can insert it into the front needle holder.
  • Using the 'slot' in the back needle holder, push the back of the needle into place until it snaps into the appropriate hole.
  • Go to step 2 and repeat for all 2 hooks/needles.
    • The hooks are designed to capture an M2 nut, and have an M2 bolt threaded threw them. String can be looped around the bolt and then secured using the set-screw. The "uncond_cylinder_catch" can be used to unconditionally advance to the next punch card after every read operation (such as in the operation of a simple loom), by mounting it directly on the frame. The "cond_cylinder_catch" and "cylinder catch frame" can be used to only advance to the next punch card when a condition is met (i.e. when the end of the cond_cylinder_catch lever is pulled downwards, swinging the end of the catch up underneath the cylinder end and forcing it to rotate). It is designed to pair with three of these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:101068 (one hook for both sides of the counter, and one for the 'zero-detect arm').

comments.text: This is amazing Chris!  While I was doodling ideas for a mechanical loom (which is as far as I've had time to get!) I was contemplating how it might be simpler to have cards that had protrusions rather than holes.  The protrusions could theoretically directly drive levers.  The cards wouldn't stack neatly, but you might be able to devise a mechanism that was simpler than the original Jacquard mechanism.
